description: Twenty-three trees, each paired with a basalt stone, line a street in Chelsea, continuing an urban project started by German Fluxus artist Joseph Beuys.

description: landmark interior

description: Church in Manhattan holds the bloody sock of Padre Pio, among with many other unusual relics.

name: 23 St
description: Stunningly detailed mosaics in a New York subway station bring life to the Weimaraners of artist William Wegman's work—and to thousands of commutes.

name: Livingston Library
description: A good place to research the Freemasons, esoterica, occultism, and hermeticism.

name: Poster House
description: The first museum in the United States dedicated entirely to posters.

description: A Manhattan courthouse hides a small but scathing memorial to Holocaust injustice.

name: Senator Roscoe Conkling Monument
description: A 19th-century politician who died after walking home in a blizzard is honored with this Manhattan statue.

description: A small part of lower Manhattan is actually made from a bit of England.

description: The name of this famed hospital was once a byword for the horrors of medical and psychiatric care.

name: Holographic Studios
description: The world's oldest hologram gallery and the labyrinthine laser laboratory of a holography pioneer.

name: Rose Hill Historic House
description: The origins of midtown Manhattan's anachronistic wooden farmhouse remain a mystery.

name: Chester A. Arthur Home
description: The only remaining building in New York to see the inauguration of a president is being slowly overtaken by a grocery store.

name: Wizard of Park Ave Clock
description: A whimsical, but often overlooked clock in Park Avenue.

name: The Church of the Transfiguration
description:
This Fifth Avenue church has long been the favored worshiping place of Broadway actors and vaudeville performers. 
Built in neo-Gothic style, Transfiguration has 14th century stained glass, elegant chapels and a picturesque garden. The church provided sanctuary to African-Americans during the Civil War and has a long-time association with the acting community. Thousands of couples were married at the church during World War II.; This Fifth Avenue church has long been the favored worshiping place of Broadway actors and vaudeville performers.

name: The Gilded Lady Mural by Tristan Eaton
description: A vibrant, 100-foot-tall mural dedicated to Evelyn Nesbit, the tragic icon of the Gilded Age.

name: 45 W 28th St
description: Remnants of Tin Pan Alley The one-time epicenter of American songwriting is now a little remembered Manhattan commercial block.

name: Conjuring Arts Research Center
description: Unlock the secrets of the conjuring arts.

name: Gimbel's Bridge
description: A three-story copper skybridge connects two Manhattan buildings with Art Deco luxury.

name: General William Jenkins Worth Monument
description: one of only 2 monuments (other is Grant's tomb) that also serves as a mausoleum

name: National Academy of Design
description: After eight decades on the Upper East Side, the National Academy of Design opened a new exhibition space in the heart of Chelsea in September 2023. Designed by Bade Stageberg Cox, the 7,800 sq ft space hosts changing exhibitions of contemporary art and architecture and is a hub for the Academy’s community of Academicians, a group of 450 leading artists and architects.

name: Andrew Heiskell Braille and Talking Book Library
Space Billiard Pool Hall & Sports Bar | Koreatown NYC
Patent Pending
description: Nikola Tesla's former home contains an homage hidden from plain sight.

name: The New School
description: Camilo Egas Mural - After surviving abandonment, this powerful Latin American mural is alive again

name: Kadampa Meditation Center New York City
Third Cemetery of the Spanish- Portuguese Synagogue
St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church
description: Located in the tourist-heavy Garment District, this Roman Catholic parish church was built in 1892 to cater to what was then a rapidly changing neighborhood. Constructed in the traditional Gothic Revival style, it’s known for being home to one of the largest mosaics in the country, The Glorification of the Mother of Jesus. The church is also known for operating one of the country’s longest-running breadlines, started during the Great Depression to feed the hungry.

name: The National Arts Club
description:
Nestled in history-steeped Gramercy Park, the National Arts Club is a home for the arts in the heart of New York City. Since 1906, the Club has been based in the Samuel Tilden Mansion, a national historic landmark and beautifully preserved example of Victorian Gothic residential architecture.

Today, the National Arts Club operates as a 501(c)(3) nonprofit and offers more than 150 free programs to the public, including exhibitions, theatrical and musical performances, lectures, and readings, attracting an audience of over 25,000 New Yorkers and visitors alike. Featured programs focus on all disciplines of the arts.

name: Rubin Museum of Art
description: unrivaled collection of himalayan art, housed in one-time Barneys flagship store

name: M & S Schmalberg
description: When Morris and Sam Schmalberg entered the flower business in 1916, the New York City Garment District produced most women’s and children’s fashion apparel in the United States. By the 1940s, dozens of “flower guys” were manufacturing fabric flowers. Today, M&S Schmalberg is the last of its kind in America, surviving as a domestic factory in a world dominated by imported goods. The company has evolved to focus on specialty custom fabric flower projects for couture fashion designers, milliners, and costume designers.

name: Marble Collegiate Church
description: Opening its doors in 1854, Marble Collegiate Church is a beautiful example of Romanesque Revival architecture with Gothic influences, made world-famous by Dr. Norman Vincent Peale. This city landmark boasts an impressive marble exterior and bell tower. Once inside, visitors will discover a finely detailed interior featuring beautiful stained glass windows—two designed by Tiffany—and a newly designed pipe organ.

name: Friends Seminary
description:
Located atop the Friend Seminary‘s 16th Street campus, James Turrell’s Leading (2023) is a meeting room in the sky—a spiritual space for silence and contemplation and a physical manifestation of the K-12 Quaker school’s mission.

One of more than eighty-five Skyspaces—but the only one attached to a K-12 school—Leading is a specifically proportioned chamber where viewers have a unique and personal experience of the sky through a knife-edged aperture in the roof. A softly lit interior combined with the changing light of the sky above provides a dramatic experience for the viewer. Benches line the perimeter of the enclosed space, and LED lights, which surround the aperture inside and outside the chamber, shift colors to affect the viewer’s perception of the sky. Based on the science of how humans perceive light, the individual experience is the actual work itself.

name: Official Ritual
description: idden behind a discreet black door in Chelsea is a little alleyway that leads to an 18th century home where you can partake in sound meditations, weekend workshops, and special wellness events. it’s a dedicated sound meditation space
